ud4.8:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ud4.8:1.3: Now at that time the Buddha was honored, respected, revered, venerated, and esteemed. And he received robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
ud4.8:1.4: And the mendicant Saṅgha was also honored, respected, revered, venerated, and esteemed. And they received robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
ud4.8:1.5: But the wanderers who followed other paths were not honored, respected, esteemed, revered, and venerated. And they didn’t receive robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
ud4.8:2.1: Then those wanderers who followed other paths, unable to bear the esteem of the mendicant Sangha, approached the female wanderer Sundarī and said,
ud4.8:2.2: “Sister, are you able to do something for the welfare of your kin?”
ud4.8:2.5: I’d even give my life for the welfare of my kin.”
ud4.8:3.1: “Well then, sister, frequently visit Jeta’s Grove.”
ud4.8:3.2: “Yes, venerables,” she replied, and did as they asked.
ud4.8:4.2: that Sundarī had been clearly seen by many people frequently visiting Jeta’s Grove,
ud4.8:4.3: they killed her and dumped her in the ditch around Jeta’s Grove. Then they went to see King Pasenadi of Kosala and said to him,
ud4.8:4.4: “Great king, we cannot find the female wanderer Sundarī.”
ud4.8:4.6: “But where do you suspect she is?”
ud4.8:5.1: So the wanderers searched Jeta’s Grove. They pulled her body up from the ditch where they had dumped it, and lifted it on a bier. Having entered Sāvatthī, they went from street to street, from square to square, complaining to people:
ud4.8:6.1: “See the deed of the Sakyan ascetics!
ud4.8:6.2: Shameless are these Sakyan ascetics, immoral and wicked. They are liars and fake celibates.
ud4.8:6.3: Sure, they claim to be of principled and moral conduct, to be celibate, truthful, ethical, and of good character.
ud4.8:6.4: But they have no asceticism, no spirituality.
ud4.8:6.5: Asceticism and spirituality are lost to them!
ud4.8:6.6: Where is their asceticism, where their spirituality?
ud4.8:6.7: They have abandoned asceticism and spirituality!
ud4.8:6.8: How on earth can a man, having done a man’s business, kill a woman!”
ud4.8:7.1: Then at that time when the people of Sāvatthī saw the mendicants they abused and insulted them with rude, harsh words:
ud4.8:8.1: “Shameless are these Sakyan ascetics, immoral, wicked, liars, and fake celibates.
ud4.8:8.2: Sure, they claim to be of principled and moral conduct, to be celibate, truthful, ethical, and of good character.
ud4.8:8.3: But they have no asceticism, no spirituality.
ud4.8:8.4: Asceticism and spirituality are lost to them!
ud4.8:8.5: Where is their asceticism, where their spirituality?
ud4.8:8.6: They have abandoned asceticism and spirituality!
ud4.8:8.7: How on earth can a man, having done a man’s business, kill a woman!”
ud4.8:9.1: Then several mendicants robed up in the morning and, taking their bowls and robes, entered Sāvatthī for alms.
ud4.8:9.2: Then, after the meal, when they returned from alms-round, they went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what was happening.
ud4.8:11.1: “That rumor, mendicants, won’t last long. It will only be seven days, then it will vanish.
ud4.8:11.3: So you may respond to those critics with this verse.”
ud4.8:12.2: as does one who denies what they did.
ud4.8:12.3: Both are equal in the hereafter,
ud4.8:13.1: The mendicants memorized that verse in the Buddha’s presence, then used it to respond to those critics.
ud4.8:15.2: “These Sakyan ascetics didn’t do it, it was not done by them, they swear it.”
ud4.8:15.3: That rumor didn’t last long. It was seven days, then it vanished.
ud4.8:16.1: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
ud4.8:17.2: How well said this was by the Buddha:
ud4.8:17.3: ‘That rumor, mendicants, won’t last long. It will only be seven days, then it will vanish.’
ud4.8:18.1: Then, knowing the meaning of this, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
ud4.8:19.1: “People out of control stab with words,
ud4.8:19.2: like they stab a tusker in battle with darts.
ud4.8:19.3: When they hear a harsh word spoken,
ud4.8:19.4: a mendicant should endure with no anger in heart.”
